across.text: Primitive sea creature can die swimming round waving nori
across.explanation: CRINOIDEAN(i.e. “primitive sea creature”). Solution is an anagram (indicated by “swimming”) of CAN DIE wrapped around another anagram (indicated by “waving”) of NORI, like so: C(RINO)IDEAN. Wordplay was fairly obvious but needed a brute force of my Chambers to nail it.

across.text: Analytical way of looking at income sector?
across.explanation: ECONOMETRICS. “Way of looking at” indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of INCOME SECTOR. Within the context of the clue, the solution could well be an analytical way of looking at the income sector.

across.text: Don’t take as much junk?
across.explanation: USELESS(i.e. “junk”). When read as USE LESS the solution also satisfies “don’t take as much”.

across.text: Church primate with gold hat
across.explanation: CHAPEAU(i.e. a French “hat”). Solution is CH (a recognised abbreviation of “church”) followed by APE (i.e. “primate”) and AU (chemical symbol of “gold”).

across.text: Is untruthful about drink? An understatement
across.explanation: LITOTES(i.e. “an understatement” – an example of litotes in action is saying “he was not a little drunk”, mean he was absolutlely plastered). Solution is LIES (i.e. “is untruthful”) wrapped “about” TOT (i.e. “drink”), like so: LI(TOT)ES.

across.text: Drugs provided by jerks after party
across.explanation: DOPE(i.e. “drugs”). Solution is PE (i.e. “jerks” – Hmm. I’m tempted to call bullshit on this. To the best of my knowledge, jerk is a weightlifting discipline, while PE is a recognised abbreviation of “physical education”. Call me weird, but any school that puts weightlifting into their PE classes would be up for child cruelty toot sweet. Maybe I’m wrong. Maybe the curriculum has changed and the setter’s kids are all built like brick shithouses…) preceded by or placed “after” DO (i.e. “party”), like so: DO-PE.[EDIT: As has been noted in a few comments, “jerks” appears to be a reference to physical education from aways-back. Chambers also has this definition: “a movement in physical exercises”. Maybe I’m from a much more cynical generation. If any PE teacher at our school asked us all to jerk for him he’d be up in front of the beak sharpish. – LP]

across.text: Drawing of a dandy, not American
across.explanation: DOODLE(i.e. “drawing”). Solution is YANKEE DOODLE “DANDY”, without the YANKEE (indicated by “not American”).

across.text: Relax rule, we hear, and hold back
across.explanation: RESTRAIN(i.e. “hold back”). Solution is REST (i.e. “relax”) followed by a homophone (indicated by “we hear”) of REIGN (i.e. “rule”).

across.text: Enter race with hooting North Eastern loco
across.explanation: THROW ONES HAT INTO THE RING(i.e. “enter race”). “Loco” indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of WITH HOOTING NORTH EASTERN.

across.text: Some just read lever here?
across.explanation: TREADLE. “Some” indicates the solution is hidden in the clue, like so: JUS(T READ LE)VER. A treadle is a “lever” worked by the foot to work a machine.

across.text: Submissive old criminal about to pass on
across.explanation: OBEDIENT(i.e. “submissive”). Solution is O (a recognised abbreviation of “old”) and BENT (i.e. “criminal”) wrapped “about” DIE (i.e. “to pass on”), like so: O-BE(DIE)NT.

across.text: One giving money embraces Republican appeal
across.explanation: PRAYER(i.e. “appeal”). Solution is PAYER (i.e. “one giving money”) wrapped around or “embracing” R (a recognised abbreviation of “Republican”), like so: P(R)AYER.

across.text: Mountain cat den, strangely clean
across.explanation: UNCONTAMINATED(i.e. “clean”). “Strangely” indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of MOUNTAIN CAT DEN.

across.text: Apple tree ain’t better if skins are removed
across.explanation: REINETTE(i.e. a variety of “apple” – did a Google image search. Yup. Looks like an apple.) Solution is derived by removing the first and last letters (indicated by “if skins are removed”) of TREE AIN’T BETTER. One gotten purely through the wordplay, TBH.

across.text: Fake article providing cover under corporation, once
across.explanation: CODPIECE(i.e. “cover under corporation, once” – “corporation” is an old word used to refer to a belly, often a pot-belly. Codpieces, meanwhile, are pouches that “cover” a chap’s bits and pieces). When read as COD PIECE, the solution also satisfies “fake article”.

across.text: Short testimonial that leads to another piece of work?
across.explanation: CROSS-REFERENCE(i.e. “that leads to another piece of work”). Solution is CROSS (i.e. “short”, both taken to mean angry) followed by REFERENCE (i.e. “testimonial”).

across.text: Gurnard in pies, regularly hard to digest?
across.explanation: UNRIPE(i.e. “hard to digest”). “Regularly” indicates the solution is derived by taking every other letter of GURNARDINPIES.

across.text: National flag followed by hard crew
across.explanation: IRISHMAN(i.e. “national”). Solution is IRIS (i.e. “flag” – one definition of “flag” is a plant of the iris family), “followed by” H (a recognised abbreviation of “hard” used in grading pencils) and MAN (i.e. “crew” – both taken as verbs, as in to man or crew something).

across.text: Search two New England states, united with Canadian region
across.explanation: MANHUNT(i.e. “search”). Solution is MA and NH (i.e. “two New England states”, specifically Massachusetts and New Hampshire), followed by U (a recognised abbreviation of “united”) and NT (i.e. “Canadian region”, specifically its Northwest Territories).

across.text: College initially incorporated by Wolseley
across.explanation: LONDON SCHOOL OF ECONOMICS(i.e. “college”). “Initially incorporated by” indicates the initials of the college have been hidden in WO(LSE)LY.

across.text: Lively one entering the next day
across.explanation: SPIRITED(i.e. “lively”). Solution to “the next” clue is SPRITE. “Entering” I (i.e. “[Roman numeral] one”) into this and then following it with D (a recognised abbreviation of “day”) nets you the solution, like so: SP(I)RITE-D. Took a while to twig. Sometimes you just don’t see ‘em.

across.text: Fairy Queen’s involved in malice
across.explanation: SPRITE(i.e. “fairy”). Solution is R (a recognised abbreviation of Regina, Latin for “queen”) placed or “involved” in SPITE (i.e. “malice”), like so: SP(R)ITE.

across.text: Pine used in trial for making tea chest?
across.explanation: ACHE(i.e. “pine” or to long for). “In” indicates the solution is hidden in the clue, like so: TE(A CHE)ST. The fuller “in trial for making tea chest” riffs on how ACHE has been slotted into TEST to make “tea chest”.

across.text: Highest point is always estimated
across.explanation: MountEVEREST(i.e. “highest point”). Solution is EVER (i.e. “always”) followed by EST (a recognised abbreviation of “estimated”).

across.text: Stupid person wrapping present cut cigar
across.explanation: CHEROOT(i.e. “cigar”). Solution is COOT (i.e. “stupid person”) “wrapped” around HERE (i.e. “present”) once its last letter has been removed (indicated by “cut”), like so: C(HER)OOT.

across.text: UK employment scheme in which some get their cards?
across.explanation: NEW DEAL. Solution satisfies “UK employment scheme” launched by New Labour in the late 1990s, and “in which some get their [playing] cards”.

across.text: Aid institute to change posture
across.explanation: ATTITUDINISE(i.e. “posture”). “To change” indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of AID INSTITUTE. One of those words that’d see anyone laughed out of a normal conversation, and rightly so.

across.text: Way of working with general builder in goldmine
across.explanation: MONEYMAKER(i.e. “goldmine”). Solution is MO (i.e. “way of working”, specifically a recognised abbreviation of Modus Operandi) followed by Michel NEY (popularly known as Marshal Ney, he was one of Napoleon’s Marshals of the Empire – a Marshal is the French equivalent of a “General” here in the UK) and MAKER (i.e. “builder”). Hello, Wikipedia!

down.text: State seizure success in hoax gallery turned up
down.explanation: COUP DETAT(i.e. “state seizure”). Solution is UP (i.e. “success”) placed “in” COD (i.e. “hoax”) and followed by TATE (i.e. “gallery”) once this latter has been reversed (indicated by “turned up” – this being a down clue), like so: CO(UP)D-ETAT.

down.text: Mostly untrained, I stop protecting chief engineer new to the job
down.explanation: INEXPERIENCED(i.e. “new to the job”). Solution is INEXPERT (i.e. “untrained”) with the last letter removed (indicated by “mostly”) and the remainder followed by I and END (i.e. “stop”) once this latter has been wrapped around or “protecting” CE (a recognised abbreviation of “chief engineer”), like so: INEXPER-I-EN(CE)D.

down.text: Sign name in Latin when dispatching note
down.explanation: OMEN(i.e. “sign”). Solution is NOMEN (i.e. “name in Latin”) with the initial N removed (indicated by “when despatching note”, N being a recognised abbreviation of “note”).

down.text: Unfortunate innocent caused shame
down.explanation: DISCOUNTENANCE(i.e. “shame”). “Unfortunate” indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of INNOCENT CAUSED.

down.text: No straight line in bar code
down.explanation: ARC(i.e. “no straight line” – an arc is a section of a circle’s circumference). “In” indicates the solution is hidden in the clue, like so: B(AR C)ODE.

down.text: Revolutionary women’s champ?
down.explanation: CHEW(i.e. “champ”). Solution is CHE Guevara (i.e. “revolutionary”, and catnip for setters everywhere) followed by W (a recognised abbreviation of “women”).

down.text: Not available, posh chairs? Disgusting
down.explanation: NAUSEATING(i.e. “disgusting”). Solution is N/A (a recognised abbreviation of “not applicable”) followed by U (a recognised abbreviation taken to mean the “upper” class, i.e. “posh”) and SEATING (i.e. “chairs”).

down.text: I cheered up, friend being around to provide influence
down.explanation: MILITATE(i.e. to have weight or “provide influence”). Solution is I and LIT (i.e. “cheered up”) both placed in MATE (indicated by “friend being around”), like so: M(I-LIT)ATE.

down.text: Don’t rate her out of shape figure
down.explanation: TETRAHEDRON(i.e. “figure”). “Out of shape” indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of DON’T RATE HER. A recent repeat fromtwo weeks ago, which is disappointing. What with PENTAHEDRONlast weekit seems we’ve hit upon the setters’ latest mania. My vote is for CUBICUBOCTAHEDRON next week. Make it so, setters.(Claps twice for emphasis.)

down.text: How decades are arranged if years hot up
down.explanation: INTENSIFY(i.e. “hot up”). Solution is IN TENS (i.e. “how decades are arranged”) followed by IF and then Y (a recognised abbreviation of “years”).

down.text: Frame elite regiment with heroin
down.explanation: SASH(i.e. a window “frame”). Solution is SAS (i.e. “elite regiment”, specifically the Special Air Service) followed by H (street name of “heroin”).

down.text: Tree cutting behind schedule – cut deeply
down.explanation: LACERATE(i.e. “cut deeply”). Solution is ACER (i.e. “tree”) placed in or “cutting” LATE (i.e. “behind schedule”), like so: L(ACER)ATE.

down.text: Oppressive awkward situation I found in December
down.explanation: DESPOTIC(i.e. “oppressive”). Solution is SPOT (i.e. “awkward situation”) and I both placed or “found in” DEC (a recognised abbreviation of “December”), like so: DE(SPOT-I)C.

down.text: Country garden under sweet williams initially
down.explanation: SWEDEN(i.e. “country”). Solution is EDEN (i.e. “garden [in The Bible]”) preceded by or “placed under” – this being a down clue – S and W (i.e. “sweet williams initially”, i.e. the first letters of “sweet” and “williams”), like so: SW-EDEN.

down.text: Cruel first piece in Greek Scrabble for Plato and second son
down.explanation: PITILESS(i.e. “cruel”). Solution is PI TILE (i.e. “first piece in Greek Scrabble for Plato” – Scrabble uses lettered TILEs. The “first” letter of “Plato” is P, its equivalent being PI in the Greek alphabet) followed by S (a recognised abbreviation of “second”) and S (ditto “son”).

down.text: Cause to resent a confused veggie eating rook
down.explanation: AGGRIEVE(i.e. “cause to resent”). Solution is A followed by an anagram (indicated by “confused”) of VEGGIE wrapped around or “eating” R (a recognised abbreviation of “rook” used in chess), like so: A-GG(R)IEVE.

down.text: Male working out with fine pectorals standing proud
down.explanation: SELF-IMPORTANCE(i.e. “standing proud” – Hmm. One of those where the setter’s desire to write a good clue ends up leaving considerable stretch marks on the English language). Solution is an anagram (indicated by “working out”) of M (a recognised abbreviation of “male”) and FINE PECTORALS.

down.text: Break link with relative about publisher
down.explanation: UNCOUPLE(i.e. “break link”). Solution is UNCLE (i.e. “relative”) wrapped “about” OUP (i.e. “publisher”, specifically the Oxford University Press), like so: UNC(OUP)LE.

down.text: Wearing an undergarment upside down is working
down.explanation: ABRASION(i.e. “wearing”). Solution is A BRA (i.e. “an undergarment”) followed by IS reversed (indicated by “upside down” – this being a down clue) and ON (i.e. “working”), like so: A-BRA-SI-ON.

down.text: Chaincap, sausance or lipalip, say? Only joking!
down.explanation: TONGUE-IN-CHEEK(i.e. “only joking”). Clue plays on how different languages or TONGUES have been placed IN different words for CHEEK, like so CHA(INCA)P, SAU(SAN)CE and L(IPAL)IP.

down.text: Regretted horse nipping queen when mounted in fine ceremony
down.explanation: GRANDEUR(i.e. “fine ceremony”). Solution is RUED (i.e. “regretted”) followed by NAG (i.e. “horse”) wrapped around or “nipping” R (a recognised abbreviation of Regina, “queen” in Latin). The whole is then reversed (indicated by “when mounted” – this being a down clue), like so: G(R)AN-DEUR.

down.text: I am in favour – one day in port is wasteful
down.explanation: IMPROVIDENT(i.e. “wasteful”). Solution is I’M (a contraction of “I am”) followed by PRO (i.e. “in favour of”) and VENT (i.e. “port”, both outlets) once this latter has been wrapped around I (i.e. “[Roman numeral] one”) and D (a recognised abbreviation of “day”), like so: I’M-PRO-V(I-D)ENT.

down.text: Contingent charged party millions
down.explanation: RANDOM(i.e. “contingent” – both taken to mean accidental or by chance – another I’m not entirely on board with, but then I’m just some bloke on the internet). Solution is RAN (i.e. “charged [towards something]”) followed by DO (i.e. “party”) and M (a recognised abbreviation of “millions”).

down.text: Cleric’s strange charade over swindle
down.explanation: ARCHDEACON(i.e. “cleric”). Solution is an anagram (indicated by “strange”) of CHARADE followed by CON (i.e. “swindle”), like so: ARCHDEA-CON.

down.text: More sensible about coin coming back into currency
down.explanation: RENASCENT(i.e. “coming back into currency” – a twisty bit of wordplay by the setter, here, taking “currency” to mean the here and now. Renascent means “coming into renewed life”(Chambers)). Solution is SANER (i.e. “more sensible”) reversed (indicated by “about”) and followed by CENT (i.e. “coin”), like so: RENAS-CENT.

down.text: Space launch low over poles, hard to put up
down.explanation: MOONSHOT(i.e. “space launch”, specifically one aiming for the moon). Solution is MOO (i.e. “low”, taken to mean the noise a cow makes – another pet play of setters) followed by NS (i.e. “poles”, i.e. recognised abbreviations of North and South), then H (a recognised abbreviation of “hard”) and TO reversed (indicated by “put up” – this being a down clue), like so: MOO-NS-H-OT.

down.text: Small hawk dropped in to rip in small pieces
down.explanation: TESSELLAR(i.e. “[paving or mosaic] in small pieces”). Solution is S (a recognised abbreviation of “small”) and SELL (i.e. “[to] hawk”) “dropped into” TEAR (i.e. “to rip”) like so: TE(S-SELL)AR.[EDIT: Thanks to Sue in the comments for the typo fix. I’d ran out of Ls. – LP]

down.text: Helped when sister is getting over boy
down.explanation: ASSISTED(i.e. “helped”). Solution is AS (i.e. “when”) followed by SIS (a recognised abbreviation of “sister”) and TED (i.e. “boy”, basically a boy’s name).

down.text: Try one’s luck with a foreign character
down.explanation: BETA(i.e. “foreign character”, specifically the second letter of the Greek alphabet). Solution is BET (i.e. “try one’s luck”) followed by A.

down.text: The French succeeded not so much
down.explanation: LESS(i.e. “not so much”). Solution is LES (i.e. “the French”, i.e. the French for “the”) followed by S (a recognised abbreviation of “succeeded”).

down.text: Be immersed with wife in computer game
down.explanation: SWIM(i.e. “be immersed with”). Solution is W (a recognised abbreviation of “wife”) placed “in” SIM (i.e. “computer game”, specifically a recognised abbreviation of a “simulation”, I believe, as opposed to EA’sSimsseries).

down.text: Pair of books about keeping whiskey
down.explanation: TWO(i.e. “pair”). Solution is OT (i.e. “books”, specifically the Old Testament of The Bible) reversed (indicated by “about”) and wrapped around or “keeping” W (“whiskey” in the phonetic alphabet), like so: T(W)O.
